command.headquarters_location: Gharyan, Libya (July-August); Forward deployment Egyptian border (September)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for offensive operations. Division concentrated with 10th Army for invasion of Egypt (September 13, 1940). Supply lines from Tripoli (650km) adequate for initial offensive phase. Primary constraints: limited water transport capacity in desert, dependence on coastal road for bulk supplies.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1940-Q3 (July-September) - Peak summer transitioning to early autumn
weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert, transitioning to Egyptian border terrain (September)

tactical_doctrine.role: Offensive operations as part of 10th Army invasion of Egypt (September 1940). Auto-transportable division capable of limited operational mobility using division trucks for phased movement of infantry battalions. Transitioned from garrison (July-August) to forward deployment (September).
special_capabilities: Auto-transportable designation - could move one infantry battalion at a time using division trucks
Acclimatized to desert conditions from formation in Libya (1937)
Shared regimental depot structure with 25th Division 'Bologna' (Campania recruiting region)
Prepared for offensive operations with 10th Army concentration
known_issues: Only partial motorization - could not move entire division simultaneously
Dependent on horse-drawn transport for artillery and heavy equipment
Limited anti-tank capability (only 8x 47mm guns) - vulnerable to British armor
Weak anti-aircraft defense - no organic AA guns
Obsolete medium machine guns (Fiat-Revelli Mod. 1914 from WWI)
Short-range artillery (75mm and 100mm pieces from WWI)
Extended supply lines from Tripoli (650km) for sustained operations
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division formed specifically for Libyan service in 1937. Troops acclimatized to extreme summer heat (peak temperatures 45-50°C in Q3). Water discipline maintained with 4.5 liters per person per day allocation. Limited motorization supplemented by extensive use of mule and horse transport for desert operations.

scenario_suitability: Italian invasion of Egypt (September 13-18, 1940) - opening phase
Early Western Desert Campaign scenarios (pre-Operation Compass)
Training scenarios for Italian auto-transportable divisions
special_rules: 8 Million Bayonets (roll for motivation/skill - see Italian army special rules)
Auto-transportable (limited mobility - can move one battalion per turn using division trucks)
Desert Garrison (acclimatized to heat, +1 on water discipline checks)
Offensive Spirit (September 1940) - Division morale boosted for initial offensive operations

source: Battlegroup Game - Avanti Italian Forces (wargaming supplement)
TME 30-420 Italian Military Forces 1943 (US Army intelligence manual)
Nafziger Collection - Organization of Italian Divisions 1939-1943
Tessin, Georg - Verbände und Truppen der deutschen Wehrmacht und Waffen-SS im Zweiten Weltkrieg (reference for Italian allied units)
Standard Italian Binary Division TO&E 1940 (composite organizational data)
Historical records of Italian invasion of Egypt (September 1940)

commander.name.reason: Italian division commander rosters for 1940-Q3 Libya operations not available in accessible sources. Italian military archives (Archivio dell'Ufficio Storico dello Stato Maggiore dell'Esercito) not accessible.
sources_checked: Historical accounts of September 1940 Egyptian invasion
commander.name.mitigation: Check Italian official histories (Storia Militare series) or divisional war diaries if available in future research

anti_aircraft.reason: Standard Italian binary division TO&E called for 8x 20mm Breda AA guns in mechanized AA troop. However, sources conflict on whether Sabratha Division (auto-transportable, not fully motorized) had full AA complement in September 1940. Some sources indicate AA guns attached at corps level rather than organic to division.
anti_aircraft.estimate_method: Conservative estimate: 0 organic AA guns, assuming corps-level AA attachment
anti_aircraft.mitigation: Check divisional war diary (Diario Storico) or Italian official history for definitive equipment list
